data.title: Roman Sum
data.statement:
In ancient Rome the numeral system used was the Roman numerals. This system used letters for representing numbers, instead of the decimal figures we use nowadays:
```
1 = I      10 = X      100 = C      1000 = M
2 = II     20 = XX     200 = CC     2000 = MM
3 = III    30 = XXX    300 = CCC    3000 = MMM
4 = IV     40 = XL     400 = CD
5 = V      50 = L      500 = D
6 = VI     60 = LX     600 = DC
7 = VII    70 = LXX    700 = DCC
8 = VIII   80 = LXXX   800 = DCCC
9 = IX     90 = XC     900 = CM
```
Roman numerals are placed one after another from larger to smaller to represent the desired number. For instance:

1984 -> MCMLXXXIV (M - CM - LXXX - IV)

You must output the <<sum>> of two Roman numerals [[A]] and [[B]] as a decimal integer.
data.constraints:
Roman numerals are in upper case.
The longest Roman numeral takes 15 characters.
0 < [[A]],[[B]] < 4000
data.stubGenerator:
read A:string(16)
read B:string(16)

write A+B

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

In ancient Rome the numeral system used was the Roman numerals. This system used letters for representing numbers, instead of the decimal figures we use nowadays:

1 = I      10 = X      100 = C      1000 = M
2 = II     20 = XX     200 = CC     2000 = MM
3 = III    30 = XXX    300 = CCC    3000 = MMM
4 = IV     40 = XL     400 = CD
5 = V      50 = L      500 = D
6 = VI     60 = LX     600 = DC
7 = VII    70 = LXX    700 = DCC
8 = VIII   80 = LXXX   800 = DCCC
9 = IX     90 = XC     900 = CM

Roman numerals are placed one after another from larger to smaller to represent the desired number. For instance:

1984 -> MCMLXXXIV (M - CM - LXXX - IV)

You must output the sum of two Roman numerals A and B as a decimal integer.




   

      
Input

      
Line 1: Roman number A
Line 2: Roman number B

   

   

      
Output

      
Line 1: The sum of A and B

   

   

      
Constraints

      
Roman numerals are in upper case.
The longest Roman numeral takes 15 characters.
0 < A,B < 4000

   

   

      
Example

      

         

            
Input

            
I
II

         

         

            
Output

            
3
